Gordon, Jim et al,
The illustrations for lots 251 & 253 have the numbers transposed, the Ezo
piece (253) does not have a real blade. Lot 252 the hamon runs off and the
blade is worn.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: "Gordon Robson" <robsongo@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, November 07, 2003 11:13 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] anyone for a piece of history


: Hi Jim,
:
:
:
: There is one at Choshu-ya. It was out on display last weekend. It is very
: similar to the first one listed below except that the kozuka and kogai are
: intact. Absolutely killer. I wonder why the Tegai Kanenaga inside is not
: shown? Or is that a stupid question?
:
:
:
: Gordon
:
:
:
: -----Original Message-----
: From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
: Sent: Friday, November 07, 2003 2:45 PM
: To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
: Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] anyone for a piece of history
:
:
:
: Yes, the second one.  I won't be bidding, but I'd like to have a look at
it.
: I'm not aware of any others of that type outside of Japan or of any better
: ones currently on the market.  Does anyone know of one?
:
: Jim
:
:
:   Hi Jim, found these two
:
:   http://tinyurl.com/u0wl
:
:
:   This one is pretty interesting, I assume this is the one you were
: mentioning.
:   http://tinyurl.com/u0wo
:
:   Rich
